intro.name: Elk
intro.intro: The elk is a rare animal in the world. Since its face is as long as that of a horse, its hoof as big as that of an ox, its tail as long as that of donkey, and its horn like that of deer, Chinese dub it as “nondescript”.

feathers.title: Long Face
feathers.text: Elks live in plain swamps. The long face allows it to put its mouth into the water to eat aquatic plants.

feathers.title: Long Horns
feathers.text: Horns are edge tools of male elks to fight and show off to win the favor of females.

feathers.title: Hoofs
feathers.text: Wide hoof and aponeurosis reduce the pressure on the hoofs when they hit the ground, helping them to walk on muddy wetlands without sinking.

feathers.title: Tail
feathers.text: The wetland environment breeds more mosquitoes and flies, and the long tail is handy in driving them away from the buttocks.

culture.text:
The final habitat of wild elks is the coastal area near the Yangtze River estuary. They are very fond of warm and humid marsh waters, and even like to touch the sea water and eat seaweed.

Through observation, the ancient Chinese discovered that elks could create a large stretch of mudflat when stepping in waterweed-rich swamps, and rice grew particularly well in such an environment. People immediately followed the elks to open up large patches of mud ponds for rice planting. Success was achieved. To commemorate this discovery, the Chinese ancestors named the deer associated with rice as “mi (weed)”, which means rice growing from under the deer’s feet.

startDialog.guide: Young elks hiding in the grass

album.text: Dafeng Yellow Sea Wetland Elk Nature Reserve, Yancheng, Jiangsu.
Nanchang, Poyang Lake Wetland Park, where elks are released into the wild.
Scattered elks in the Nanhaizi Elk Garden, Daxing, Beijing.

protection.text:
According to scientific research, as early as 3,000 years ago, there were elks inhabiting the middle and lower reaches of the Yellow River and the Yangtze River, which gradually decreased after the Han Dynasty around two thousand years ago.

By the 19th Century, there was only one group of elks left in the Royal Hunting Garden in Nanhaizi, Beijing. Shortly after being discovered by some Westerners, they were captured by the Eight-Power Allied Forces and disappeared from China. Some elks were purchased by the U.K. until 1898, expanding to a herd of 255. In the 1980s, some elks were sent back to China, often for release in the wild.

From 1985 to 1986, China imported a total of 77 elks from the United Kingdom. By now, the population of elks has grown to nearly 5,000.

In order to ensure save living conditions for elks that had returned to China, the government has established several national nature reserves and nature conservation stations. At the four native habitats of elks in three provinces, including Jiangsu and Hubei, four groups of nearly a thousand wild elks were restored, the first time in 150 years to see wild elks in China. As the population grew, the elks’ reproductive rate, survival rate, annual growth rate and other indicators ranked first in the world.

The Chinese people also maintain a good sense of protection for the elks, and expect them to continue to live freely on their native land.
